body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

side effect of repairing #3167.   test case:

```
from sqlalchemy import create_engine, Column
from sqlalchemy.types import Integer, PickleType
from sqlalchemy.ext.mutable import MutableDict
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.orm import Session

Base = declarative_base()


class MyDataClass(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'my_data'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    data = Column(
        MutableDict.as_mutable(PickleType), default={}, nullable=False)

session = Session(create_engine("sqlite:///:memory:", echo=True))
Base.metadata.create_all(session.bind)

m1 = MyDataClass()
session.add(m1)
session.flush()
assert isinstance(m1.data, MutableDict)

```

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **title** from "SQLAlchemy 1.0 behavior difference regarding colum" to "Mutable.coerce() isn't called for a column-default"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

it's not clear what we can do here.  Running validators on data against column defaults is not desirable.     Except when it is.  Do we 1. add a new feature to make it configurable whether or not an attribute event runs in this context?  2. add some new route that Mutable can use in order to run its coerce hook in this case?  3. just say that it's not appropriate to use the wrong type in a column default if you're using mutable (unlikely)?

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

Definitely not #3, because mutable needs the attribute event here just to set up the correct listening, it's more than just the coerce().   this is a refresh operation, and we listen for that; so a patch that works, though with an API issue I want to work around, is:


```
diff --git a/lib/sqlalchemy/orm/persistence.py b/lib/sqlalchemy/orm/persistence.py
index ab2d54d..4cae699 100644
--- a/lib/sqlalchemy/orm/persistence.py
+++ b/lib/sqlalchemy/orm/persistence.py
@@ -950,6 +950,11 @@ def _postfetch(mapper, uowtransaction, table,
             mapper.version_id_col in mapper._cols_by_table[table]:
         prefetch_cols = list(prefetch_cols) + [mapper.version_id_col]
 
+    if mapper.class_manager.dispatch.refresh:
+        load_evt_attrs = []
+    else:
+        load_evt_attrs = None
+
     if returning_cols:
         row = result.context.returned_defaults
         if row is not None:
@@ -957,10 +962,18 @@ def _postfetch(mapper, uowtransaction, table,
                 if col.primary_key:
                     continue
                 dict_[mapper._columntoproperty[col].key] = row[col]
+                if load_evt_attrs is not None:
+                    load_evt_attrs.append(mapper._columntoproperty[col].key)
 
     for c in prefetch_cols:
         if c.key in params and c in mapper._columntoproperty:
             dict_[mapper._columntoproperty[c].key] = params[c.key]
+            if load_evt_attrs is not None:
+                load_evt_attrs.append(mapper._columntoproperty[c].key)
+
+    if load_evt_attrs:
+        mapper.class_manager.dispatch.refresh(
+            state, uowtransaction, load_evt_attrs)
 
     if postfetch_cols:
         state._expire_attributes(state.dict,

```


the problem here is we don't have a QueryContext to use, we have a UOW object and that is not what the contract of refresh() says it is.   So adding a new event here and having mutable listen to it might be the way to go on this.

**Raphaël Slinckx wrote:**

I admit i'm a bit lost with all the options and their implications :)

In any case, there should be a warning or an assertion failure if this can't be fixed quickly, when the default type is not the same type as the column (here dict vs. MutableDict) otherwise people will get strange behaviors.

I think having a dict as default value is not necessarily a good idea, since dicts are mutable, much like having a function in python with a dict as default arg 'def foo(x={})' is not a good idea. Requiring the default to be a callable retuning a new instance of MutableDict in this case would be understandable, but it probably breaks a lot of code.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

oh sorry, that was me thinking out loud.  your job here is done :)

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- Fixed regression in the :mod:`sqlalchemy.ext.mutable` extension
as a result of the bugfix for :ticket:`3167`,
where attribute and validation events are no longer
called within the flush process.  The mutable
extension was relying upon this behavior in the case where a column
level Python-side default were responsible for generating the new value
on INSERT or UPDATE, or when a value were fetched from the RETURNING
clause for "eager defaults" mode.  The new value would not be subject
to any event when populated and the mutable extension could not
establish proper coercion or history listening.  A new event
:meth:`.InstanceEvents.refresh_flush` is added which the mutable
extension now makes use of for this use case.
fixes #3427
- Added new event :meth:`.InstanceEvents.refresh_flush`, invoked
when an INSERT or UPDATE level default value fetched via RETURNING
or Python-side default is invoked within the flush process.  This
is to provide a hook that is no longer present as a result of
:ticket:`3167`, where attribute and validation events are no longer
called within the flush process.
- Added a new semi-public method to :class:`.MutableBase`
:meth:`.MutableBase._get_listen_keys`.  Overriding this method
is needed in the case where a :class:`.MutableBase` subclass needs
events to propagate for attribute keys other than the key to which
the mutable type is associated with, when intercepting the
:meth:`.InstanceEvents.refresh` or
:meth:`.InstanceEvents.refresh_flush` events.  The current example of
this is composites using :class:`.MutableComposite`.


→ 525cc6fe0247

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

**Raphaël Slinckx wrote:**

Thanks a lot for the quick response !

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

Issue #3439 was marked as a duplicate of this issue.

issue.title: support psycopg2cffi features under their own versioning scheme

labels.name: sqlalchemy.ext
labels.description: extension modules, most of which are ORM related

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Pablo Marti ([@pmarti](https://github.com/pmarti))**

Hi there,

I have a User model class with a profile attribute marked as mutable

```
class User(db.Model):
    ...
    profile = db.Column(MutableDict.as_mutable(JSONB()))
```

This works perfectly under python2.7, but now when I issue a query using pypy 2.6 I get this:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/src/flask/flask/app.py", line 1537, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.dispatch_request()
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/src/flask/flask/app.py", line 1523, in dispatch_request
    return self.view_functions[rule.endpoint](**req.view_args)
  File "/Users/pablo/Development/drop-server/drop/api/decorators.py", line 73, in decorated_function
    .get(user_id)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/query.py", line 818, in get
    return self._get_impl(ident, loading.load_on_ident)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/query.py", line 851, in _get_impl
    return fallback_fn(self, key)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/loading.py", line 217, in load_on_ident
    return q.one()
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/query.py", line 2472, in one
    ret = list(self)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/loading.py", line 84, in instances
    util.raise_from_cause(err)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/util/compat.py", line 199, in raise_from_cause
    reraise(type(exception), exception, tb=exc_tb)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/loading.py", line 69, in instances
    rows = [proc(row) for row in fetch]
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/loading.py", line 430, in _instance
    state.manager.dispatch.load(state, context)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/event/attr.py", line 258, in __call__
    fn(*args, **kw)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/ext/mutable.py", line 428, in load
    val = cls.coerce(key, val)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/ext/mutable.py", line 638, in coerce
    return Mutable.coerce(key, value)
  File "/Users/pablo/.virtualenvs/drop/site-packages/sqlalchemy/ext/mutable.py", line 403, in coerce
    raise ValueError(msg % (key, type(value)))
ValueError: Attribute 'profile' does not accept objects of type <type 'list'>
```

Dependencies:

SQLAlchemy==1.0.4
psycopg2cffi==2.7.0
